repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
## Problem

No default way to add an empty line below/above cursor in normal mode, an edit that is done fairly often by programmers and text writers. Currently There is no way to do this without creating marks or manually navigating back to previous cursor position.

## Solution

Like tpope's unimpaired, adds `[<Space>` and `]<Space` to add an empty line above and below cursor respectively.

---

Idea based on tpope's unimpaired, implementation based on [tummetott/unimpaired.nvim](https://github.com/tummetott/unimpaired.nvim).

Closes #30779.

comment_regular_data.body:
I need some help with writing the test for this. I have the following test:

```lua
it('#tagged should add an empty line above the cursors current line', function()
  n.clear()
  n.insert([[first line]])
  n.feed('[<Space>')
  n.expect([[

  first line]])
end)
```

Which results in:
```
Passed in:
(string) 'first line'
Expected:
(string) '
first line'
```

Using `n.feed('O')` instead (which should have the same behaviour, but leave cursor in insert mode) passes the test.

Running `VIMRUNTIME=./runtime ./build/bin/nvim` and pressing `[<Space>` works as expected: an empty line is inserted above the cursor.

I've pushed the failing tests for ease of checking out. The test is tagged with `#tagged`: `TEST_TAG=tagged make functionaltest`
Default mappings are disabled in tests by default. Look at the test added in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30983 for an example of how to test this.

Thank you! this did the trick:

```diff
it('#tagged should add an empty line above the cursors current line', function()
- n.clear()
+ n.clear({ args_rm = { '--cmd' } })
  n.insert([[first line]])
  n.feed('[<Space>')
  n.expect([[

  first line]])
end)
```

I'm not sure in which help file to put the documentation for this. And should I maybe mention this in the help section for `o` and `O`? E.g. "|]<Space>| inserts empty lines without leaving normal mode."

> And should I maybe mention this in the help section for o and O? E.g. "|]| inserts empty lines without leaving normal mode."

Yes, please. As a user, I think it would help to cross-reference these in `:help o` and `:help O`.

Saw this in the `insert.txt` doc:

> 'formatoptions' can be set to copy the comment leader when opening a new line.

It's not something that I use, but probably the expected behavior of this keymap (at least, I conceptually think of this keymap as `o` + `<Esc>`.

So I will change the implementation to the following:

```lua
vim.keymap.set('n', ']<Space>', function ()
  local cursor = vim.api.nvim_win_get_cursor(0)
  vim.cmd.norm(vim.v.count1 .. "o")
  vim.api.nvim_win_set_cursor(0, cursor)
end)
```

This _actually_ uses `o` under the hood and thus respects [`:h fo-o`](https://neovim.io/doc/user/change.html#fo-o).

> Saw this in the `insert.txt` doc:
> 
> > 'formatoptions' can be set to copy the comment leader when opening a new line.
> 
> It's not something that I use, but probably the expected behavior of this keymap (at least, I conceptually think of this keymap as `o` + `<Esc>`.
> 
> So I will change the implementation to the following:
> 
> ```lua
> vim.keymap.set('n', ']<Space>', function ()
>   local cursor = vim.api.nvim_win_get_cursor(0)
>   vim.cmd.norm(vim.v.count1 .. "o")
>   vim.api.nvim_win_set_cursor(0, cursor)
> end)
> ```
> 

No, please keep the behavior identical to vim-unimpaired. It should insert an empty line without adding a comment leader.
Sure! In that case, this PR is ready for review.

And just out of curiosity: why is identical behavior with a vim plugin more important than sharing behavior with a similar vim command? Is it because vim-unimpaired is so well known and used?

Btw, this is the reason tpope did not add support for `fo-o`:

> This behavior is very deliberate, as the reason I bothered adding these to begin with was o<Esc> was forcing comment characters where I didn't want them. I'm not sure why anyone want want a blank comment line.

Which is a fair point, wouldn't it be that this is _his_ preference and this is already something that can already be configured using `set formatoptions-=o`.

But that are my 2 cents. I don't care that much about which approach is chosen here.

1. When one uses `o` to open a new line they can use `Ctrl-U` to remove the comment leader. When one uses a Normal mode command it's harder to remove the comment leader.
2. When one uses `o` to open a new line they are more likely to add text in it. When one uses a Normal mode mapping they are more likely to keep it blank.
3. It's more convenient to have two different behaviors available at the same time instead of having to change the value of an option to switch between them.

>And just out of curiosity: why is identical behavior with a vim plugin more important than sharing behavior with a similar vim command?

The identical behavior with vim-unimpaired is not really the point (my comment was a bit misleading here), but rather that the behavior that vim-unimpaired implements is the behavior that we actually want (for the reasons tpope himself gave in your comment as well as zeertzjq's comments).

title: feat(defaults): add unimpaired empty line below/above cursor mapping
